bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Discharge of liquidator by court order

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After a society has been dissolved under section 150, the court may, on the application of a liquidator who has not been discharged by court order under section 149 (5) (b) [final meeting and dissolution], discharge the applicant as liquidator.
An application under subsection (1) must include the account of the liquidation prepared under section 149 (1) (a).

Subject to subsection (4), a court order discharging the liquidator of a society under this section discharges the liquidator from all liability in respect of any act done or default made by the liquidator in the administration of the activities and internal affairs of the society or otherwise done by that person in the person's capacity as liquidator of the society.
A court order discharging the liquidator of a society under this section

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not, except to the extent that the order expressly provides otherwise, relieve the liquidator from an obligation imposed on the liquidator under section 152, and
may be revoked on proof that the court order was obtained by fraud or by suppression or concealment of a material fact.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Retention of society's records by liquidator

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After a society has been dissolved under section 150 [dissolution on completion of liquidation], a liquidator of the society must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: retain custody or control of the society's records for a period of 3 years following the date of the dissolution or until the expiration of any shorter period the court, on the application of the liquidator, may order, and

comply with the provisions of this Act that relate to maintaining, providing access to and providing copies of those records, and, for that purpose, a reference in those provisions to the society is to be read as a reference to the liquidator.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A liquidator must ensure that all of the records the liquidator is required to keep under subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of records that are not in electronic form, are kept at an office of the liquidator in British Columbia, and
in the case of records that are in electronic form, are available for inspection at an office of the liquidator in British Columbia by means of a computer terminal or other electronic technology.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Retention of society's records by record keeper

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After a society has been dissolved under section 126 [dissolution by request of society without assets or liabilities], the record keeper of the society must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: retain custody or control of the records referred to in section 126.1 [custody of society's records by record keeper] for a period of 3 years following the date of the dissolution or until the expiration of any shorter period the court, on the application of the record keeper, may order, and
take reasonable precautions in keeping the records so as to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: keep those records in a complete state,
avoid loss or destruction of or damage to those records, and
facilitate simple, reliable and prompt access to those records.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A record keeper must ensure that all of the records referred to in section 126.1,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of records that are not in electronic form, are kept at an office of the record keeper in British Columbia, and
in the case of records that are in electronic form, are available for inspection at an office of the record keeper in British Columbia by means of a computer terminal or other electronic technology.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Duties and powers of record keeper

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On the request of a person who was, at the time of the dissolution of the society, entitled to inspect or obtain a copy of a record under sections 24 [inspection of records] to 28 [copies of financial statements], the record keeper of a society must, on the payment of any applicable fee and to the extent of the person's entitlement, provide the person with access to or, in accordance with subsection (4) of this section, a copy of the record.
The record keeper may charge, for an inspection or a copy of a record, the fee referred to in section 24 (5), 27 (3) or 28 (4), as applicable, as if the record keeper were the society.
The record keeper may impose a reasonable period of notice before which, and reasonable restrictions on the times during which, a person may inspect a record.
The record keeper must provide a copy of a record to the person seeking to obtain the copy

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by promptly sending it to the person in the manner, if any, agreed to by the record keeper and the person, or

if there is no agreement under paragraph (a), by promptly making the copy available for pick-up at the office at which the records referred to in section 126.1 [custody of society's records by record keeper] are kept.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 107 [registrar or court may order access or copies] applies in relation to the records of a society referred to in section 126.1 as if the record keeper were the society.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Filing of notices by record keeper

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A record keeper who has custody or control of the records referred to in section 126.1 [custody of society's records by record keeper] must file with the registrar a notice of change promptly after any of the following occurs:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there is a change in one or both of the record keeper's delivery address and mailing address;
the court makes an order under section 148.1 [power of court to replace record keeper] to replace the record keeper;
the court makes an order under section 152.1 (1) (a) [retention of society's records by record keeper] to shorten the period for which the record keeper must retain custody or control of the records.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a court order is made under section 148.1 or 152.1 (1) (a), the record keeper must file with the registrar, concurrently with the notice of change referred to in subsection (1) of this section, a copy of the entered court order.
After a society is dissolved under this Part, the registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: issue a certificate of dissolution showing the date and time of the dissolution, and
furnish a copy of the certificate of dissolution to the following, as applicable:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the case of a society that is dissolved under section 126 [dissolution by request of society without assets or liabilities], the record keeper;
in any other case, each liquidator of the society.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After a society is dissolved under this Part, the registrar must publish notice of the dissolution.
Subject to sections 155 and 157 [liabilities survive], when a society is dissolved under this Part, the society ceases to exist for any purpose.
Despite section 31 (3) [joint tenancy in property] of the Business Corporations Act, if a society is dissolved, any property held, immediately before the dissolution, by the society as a joint tenant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: devolves, on the dissolution, on the other joint tenants only if all of the other joint tenants are qualified recipients, and

in any other case, is deemed to be held, immediately before the dissolution, by the society and the other joint tenants, as tenants in common, but the joint tenancy among the other joint tenants, if there is more than one, is not affected.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), if, when a society is dissolved, the society has money or other property that has not been distributed, the property vests in the government unless the property is land located in British Columbia, in which case the property is deemed to escheat to the government under section 4 [escheat of land on dissolution of corporation] of the Escheat Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Dissolved societies deemed to continue for litigation purposes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite the dissolution of a society under this Part,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a legal proceeding commenced by or against the society before its dissolution may be continued as if the society had not been dissolved, and
a legal proceeding may be brought against the society within 2 years after its dissolution as if the society had not been dissolved.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a society has not provided an address for service in a legal proceeding referred to in subsection (1), records related to the proceeding may be served on the society

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by delivering the records to an individual who was a director or senior manager of the society immediately before the society was dissolved, or
in the manner the court orders.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Liability of persons who receive distributions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If it appears to the court in a legal proceeding referred to in section 155 (1) that some or all of a society's money or other property was distributed to one or more persons in anticipation of, during or as a result of the society's liquidation or dissolution, the court may, subject to subsections (2) and (4) of this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: add those persons as parties to the legal proceeding,
determine, for each of those parties, the amount for which that party is liable and the amount that party must contribute towards satisfaction of the plaintiff's claim, and
direct payment of the amounts so determined.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person is not liable under subsection (1) unless the person is added as a party within 2 years after the date on which the society was dissolved.

If a judgment is obtained in a legal proceeding against a dissolved society before or after its dissolution and it appears that some or all of the society's money or other property was distributed to a person in anticipation of, during or as a result of the society's liquidation or dissolution,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the judgment creditor may, within 2 years after the date on which the society was dissolved, bring a legal proceeding against the person to enforce the liability referred to in paragraph (b), and
the person is liable to the judgment creditor if the court is satisfied that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: some or all of the society's money or other property was distributed to the person in anticipation of, during or as a result of the society's liquidation or dissolution,

the person has had an opportunity to raise any reasonable defences to the judgment creditor's claim against the society that were not considered in a trial or summary trial in the legal proceeding in which judgment against the society was obtained, and
the amount is justly due and owing by the society to the judgment creditor.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The liability of a person in relation to a distribution referred to in subsection (1) or (3) continues despite the dissolution of the society but is limited to the value that the money or other property received by the person on that distribution had on the date of that distribution.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Subject to sections 151 (3) [discharge of liquidator by court order] and 156 (2) and (4), the liability of each member, director, senior manager or liquidator of a society that is dissolved continues and may be enforced as if the society had not been dissolved.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions and application of Division to society dissolved under former Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: applicant, in relation to an application under this Division for restoration of a society that has been dissolved, for the extension of a limited restoration or for the conversion of a limited restoration into a full restoration, means,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an application to the registrar, a related person, and
in the case of an application to the court, a related person or a person whom the court considers to be an appropriate person to make the application;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: full restoration means a restoration of a society that is not a limited restoration;
limited restoration means a restoration of a society that is for a limited period;
related person, in relation to a society that has been dissolved, means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person who, at the time of the dissolution, was a member or director of the society, or
a person who is the heir or personal or other legal representative of a person who, at the time of the dissolution, was a member of the society.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This Division applies to a society under the former Act that was dissolved under the former Act as if it were a society that was dissolved under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prerequisites to application for restoration, extension or conversion by registrar or court

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application under this Division for restoration of a dissolved society, for the extension of a limited restoration or for the conversion of a limited restoration into a full restoration may be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: filed with the registrar under section 160 [application to registrar for restoration] or 160.1 [application to registrar to extend or convert limited restoration], as applicable, or
made to the court under section 162 [application to court for restoration] or 162.1 [application to court to extend or convert limited restoration], as applicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before filing or making an application referred to in subsection (1) (a) or (b), a person must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: publish in the Gazette notice of the application, and
mail a notice of the application to the last addresses shown in the register of societies as

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the address or mailing address, as the case may be, of the registered office of the society, and
the address of each of the individuals who were the directors of the society at the time of the dissolution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before filing or making an application for restoration referred to in subsection (1) (a) or (b), a person must reserve a name under section 9 [name].
To apply to the registrar for the restoration of a society, an applicant must file with the registrar

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a restoration application, and
any other records the registrar may require.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A restoration application referred to in subsection (1) (a) must contain the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date on which the notice required under section 159 (2) (a) was published in the Gazette;
the latest date on which a notice required under section 159 (2) (b) was mailed in accordance with that provision;
the name reserved under section 9 [name] for the society and the reservation number given for that name;
the delivery address and mailing address of the registered office proposed for the society;
if the application is for a limited restoration, a statement specifying the proposed limited period of the restoration.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In respect of applications to the registrar under this section for limited restorations, the registrar may establish the maximum period of restoration that may be specified in a statement referred to in subsection (2) (e).

If a society was dissolved before the coming into force of this section, a restoration application in respect of the dissolved society may not be submitted for filing with the registrar more than 10 years after the date of the dissolution.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application to registrar to extend or convert limited restoration

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a restoration under section 161 (1) [restoration, extension or conversion by registrar] is a limited restoration, the applicant who filed the restoration application may, within the limited period of restoration and subject to this section, apply to the registrar to extend the limited restoration or convert the limited restoration into a full restoration.
To apply to the registrar for an extension or conversion of a limited restoration, the applicant must file with the registrar

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application to extend or convert the limited restoration, and
any other records the registrar may require.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application referred to in subsection (2) (a) must contain the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the information described in section 160 (2) (a), (b) and (d) [application to registrar for restoration];
if the application is for an extension of a limited restoration, a statement specifying the proposed new limited period of restoration.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In respect of applications to the registrar under this section for extensions of limited restorations, the registrar may establish the maximum period of restoration that may be specified in a statement referred to in subsection (3) (b).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Restoration, extension or conversion by registrar

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), as applicable, and unless the court orders otherwise in an entered court order, a copy of which has been filed with the registrar, after the application is filed with the registrar under section 160 [application to registrar for restoration] or section 160.1 [application to registrar to extend or convert limited restoration], the registrar, on any terms and conditions the registrar considers appropriate,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must, in the case of an application for restoration under section 160, restore the society or restore the society for the limited period set out in the application, as the case may be, and

may, in the case of an application under section 160.1, extend the limited restoration to a later date that the registrar considers appropriate or convert the limited restoration into a full restoration.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2.1), the registrar may not, under subsection (1), restore a society or convert a limited restoration of a society until 21 days after the later of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date shown in the application as the date on which notice of the application was published in the Gazette in accordance with section 159 (2) (a) [prerequisites to application for restoration, extension or conversion by registrar or court], and
the date shown in the application as the latest date on which a notice of the application was mailed in accordance with section 159 (2) (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) does not apply to the restoration of a society if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the society was dissolved under section 214 [involuntary dissolution by registrar] for one or more of the reasons set out in section 214 (1) (a) to (d), and for no other reason under that section, and
the application for restoration is filed no later than one year after the date of dissolution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may not restore a society under subsection (1) unless the reservation of a name under section 9 [name] for the society remains in effect on the date of the restoration.

Subject to section 165 [corporate property to be returned to restored society], a restoration, extension or conversion under subsection (1) of this section is without prejudice to the rights acquired by persons before the restoration, extension or conversion, as the case may be.
Before making an application to the court under this section for the restoration of a society, an applicant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide to the registrar notice of the application and a copy of any record proposed to be filed in the court registry in support of the application, and
obtain the registrar's written consent to the restoration.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An applicant may apply to the court for the restoration of a society and must, on making an application, provide to the court

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the information described in section 160 (2) (a) to (e) [application to registrar for restoration],
the registrar's written consent to the restoration, including any terms and conditions the registrar considers appropriate, and
any other information and records the court requires.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, on an application under subsection (2), the court is satisfied that it is appropriate to restore the society, the court may make an order that the society be restored and, in that order, may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: set out any terms and conditions the court considers appropriate, and
give directions and make provisions the court considers appropriate for placing the society and every other person in the same position, as nearly as may be, as if the society had not been dissolved.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 165 [corporate property to be returned to restored society], unless the court orders otherwise, an order under subsection (3) of this section is without prejudice to the rights acquired by persons before the restoration.
A court order under subsection (3) must reflect any terms and conditions referred to in subsection (2) (b).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application to court to extend or convert limited restoration

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a restoration under section 161 (1) [restoration, extension or conversion by registrar] or 163 (2) [filing of restoration application with registrar in court-ordered restoration] is a limited restoration, the applicant who filed the restoration application may, within the limited period of restoration and subject to this section, apply to the court to extend the limited restoration or convert the limited restoration into a full restoration.
Before making an application to the court under this section for the extension or conversion of a limited restoration, an applicant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide to the registrar notice of the application and a copy of any record proposed to be filed in the court registry in support of the application, and
obtain the registrar's written consent to the extension or conversion.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On making an application to the court under this section, the applicant must provide to the court

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the information described in section 160 (2) (a), (b) and (d) [application to registrar for registration],
if the application is for an extension of a limited restoration, a statement specifying the proposed new limited period of restoration,
the registrar's written consent to the extension or conversion, including any terms and conditions the registrar considers appropriate, and
any other information and records the court requires.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, on an application under subsection (1), the court is satisfied that it is appropriate to extend or convert the limited restoration of a society, the court may make an order that the limited restoration be extended or converted into a full restoration, as the case may be, and, in that order, may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: set out any terms and conditions the court considers appropriate, and
give directions and make provisions the court considers appropriate for placing the society and every other person in the same position, as nearly as may be, as if the society had not been dissolved.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 165 [corporate property to be returned to restored society], unless the court orders otherwise, an order under subsection (4) of this section is without prejudice to the rights acquired by persons before the extension or conversion, as the case may be.
A court order under subsection (4) must reflect any terms and conditions referred to in subsection (3) (c).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Filing of application in court-ordered restoration, extension or conversion

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Promptly after a court order is made under section 162 (3) [application to court for restoration] or 162.1 (4) [application to court to extend or convert limited restoration], the applicant must file with the registrar

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application that complies with section 160 (2) [application to registrar for restoration] or 160.1 (3) [application to registrar to extend or convert limited restoration], as applicable, and
concurrently with that application, the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a copy of the entered court order;
any other records the registrar may require.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), when the application is filed with the registrar under this section, the registrar must, as applicable and in accordance with the court order filed with the application,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: restore the society or restore the society for the limited period,
extend the limited restoration to a later date, or
convert the limited restoration into a full restoration.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may not restore a society under subsection (2) (a) unless the reservation of a name under section 9 [name] for the society remains in effect on the date of the restoration.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of restoration, extension or conversion

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: delivery address, in relation to the registered office of a society, means the delivery address of the registered office set out in one of the following, as applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the statement of directors and registered office of the society;
the statement of the society referred to in subsection (2) (c) or (3);

bcl:definition.bcl:text: mailing address, in relation to the registered office of a society, means the mailing address of the registered office set out in one of the following, as applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the statement of directors and registered office of the society;
the statement of the society referred to in subsection (2) (c) or (3);

bcl:definition.bcl:text: pre-transition society has the same meaning as in section 231 [definitions].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a court orders otherwise under section 162 [application to court for restoration], a society that is restored under this Division is restored

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: except in relation to the society's name, with the constitution and bylaws it had immediately before its dissolution,
with the name reserved under section 9 [name] for the society, and

subject to subsections (3) and (4), with the statement of directors and registered office that it had immediately before its dissolution except that the delivery address and mailing address of the registered office for the society are the addresses shown for that office in the restoration application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A pre-transition society is restored with one of the following statements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if, when the application for restoration is made, the pre-transition society files with the registrar an annual report, a statement setting out the delivery address and mailing address of the registered office of the society and the full name and address of each director of the society as set out in the annual report;

in any other case, a statement setting out the delivery address and mailing address of the registered office proposed in the application for restoration and the full name and address of each director of the society as set out in a record filed with the registrar immediately before its dissolution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a limited restoration of a society is extended or converted into a full restoration, on the extension or conversion, as the case may be, the society is restored with the statement of directors and registered office that it had immediately before the extension or conversion.

A society that is restored under this Division is deemed to have continued in existence as if it had not been dissolved, and proceedings may be taken as might have been taken if the society had not been dissolved.
If the restoration of a society is a limited restoration, the society is dissolved on one of the following, as applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the expiration of the limited period;

if the limited restoration is extended under section 161 [restoration, extension or conversion by registrar] or 163 [filing of application with registrar in court-ordered restoration, extension or conversion], the expiration of the extended period.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 153 (1) [registrar's duties after dissolution] does not apply in respect of the dissolution of a society under subsection (6) of this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Corporate property to be returned to restored society

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If money or other property of a society, other than property described in subsection (4) or (5), vested in the government under section 154 (3) [effect of dissolution] as a result of the society's dissolution, on the restoration of the society,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: any of that property that has not been disposed of by the government vests in the society without any deed, bill of sale or other record from the government or any action by the government, and
subject to subsection (3) of this section, the government must,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in the case of property that remains in the government's custody, return all of that property to the society,

in the case of property that has been disposed of by the government, pay to the society, out of the consolidated revenue fund, the amount of money realized by the government from the disposition of that property, and
in the case of money that has been received by the government, pay to the society, out of the consolidated revenue fund, the amount of that money.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A payment under subsection (1) (b) may be made without an appropriation other than that provision.

The government need not comply with subsection (1) (b) in relation to money or other property of a restored society unless and until the government has been reimbursed, out of the money or other property, or otherwise, for the government's costs of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: obtaining, retaining, maintaining and disposing of the money or other property, and
paying the money, and returning the other property, in accordance with that provision.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (5), title to, or an interest in, land of a society that has escheated to the government under section 4 [escheat of land on dissolution of corporation] of the Escheat Act is not, except as provided in section 4 of that Act, affected by a restoration of the society.
Title to, or an interest in, water system property of a society that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has escheated to the government under section 4 of the Escheat Act, or
has vested in the government under this Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: is not, except as provided in section 4.1 [disposal of escheated water system property] of the Escheat Act, affected by a restoration of the society.
After a society is restored or after the extension of a limited restoration or the conversion of a limited restoration into a full restoration under this Division, the registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: issue a certificate of restoration in which is recorded

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the name of the society,
the date and time of the restoration, and
in the case of a limited restoration, the date on which the period of restoration expires,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: furnish to the society

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the certificate of restoration,
a certified copy of the statement referred to in section 164 (2) (c), (3) or (4) [effect of restoration, extension or conversion], as applicable, and

a certified copy of the restoration application filed with the registrar under section 160 [application to registrar for restoration] or 163 [filing of application in court-ordered restoration, extension or conversion],

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: furnish to the applicant who filed the application a copy of the certificate of restoration, and
publish notice of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the restoration, and
the date on which any limited restoration expires.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Whether or not the requirements precedent and incidental to restoration have been complied with, a notation in the register of societies that a society has been restored is conclusive evidence for the purposes of this Act and for all other purposes that the society has been duly restored with the name, and on the date and time, shown in the register of societies.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: attorney means an attorney referred to in section 170 [attorneys];

delivery address, in relation to the head office of an extraprovincial non-share corporation, or an attorney for an extraprovincial non-share corporation, means the delivery address for that office or person, as the case may be, shown in the register of societies;
federal corporation means an extraprovincial non-share corporation that is incorporated, amalgamated, continued or otherwise formed by or under an enactment of Canada;

mailing address, in relation to the head office of an extraprovincial non-share corporation, or an attorney for an extraprovincial non-share corporation, means the mailing address for that office or person, as the case may be, shown in the register of societies;
registered extraprovincial non-share corporation means an extraprovincial non-share corporation that is registered under Division 2 [Registration].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When extraprovincial non-share corporation deemed to carry on activities in British Columbia
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Act, an extraprovincial non-share corporation is deemed to carry on activities in British Columbia if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: its name, or a name under which it carries on activities, is listed in a telephone directory, for any part of British Columbia, in which an address or telephone number in British Columbia is given for the extraprovincial non-share corporation,

its name, or a name under which it carries on activities, appears or is announced in an advertisement in which an address or telephone number in British Columbia is given for the extraprovincial non-share corporation, or
it has, in British Columbia,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a resident agent or employee, or
an office or similar place from which it carries on activities.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An extraprovincial non-share corporation must register in accordance with this Division within 60 days after it begins to carry on activities in British Columbia.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registered extraprovincial non-share corporation

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that has its head office in British Columbia may have one or more attorneys, and
in any other case, must have one or more attorneys.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Each attorney for a registered extraprovincial non-share corporation must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an individual who is resident in British Columbia,
a society, or
a company as defined in section 1 (1) [definitions] of the Business Corporations Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Each attorney for a registered extraprovincial non-share corporation is deemed to be authorized by the extraprovincial non-share corporation to accept service in British Columbia on behalf of, and receive each notice to, that extraprovincial non-share corporation.
Subject to section 170 (1) (b), an extraprovincial non-share corporation may remove an attorney by filing with the registrar a notice of removal of attorney.
Subject to subsection (3), the removal of the attorney takes effect at the beginning of the day following the date on which the notice of removal of attorney is filed with the registrar.
A removal of an attorney does not take effect unless and until the extraprovincial non-share corporation complies with section 170.
After the removal of an attorney takes effect, the registrar must furnish confirmation of the removal to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person who has been removed as an attorney for the extraprovincial non-share corporation, and
the extraprovincial non-share corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An attorney for an extraprovincial non-share corporation who intends to resign must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: give the attorney's resignation to the extraprovincial non-share corporation in writing at least 2 months before the date on which the resignation is to take effect, and
promptly after complying with the requirement set out in paragraph (a), file with the registrar a notice of resignation of attorney.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), an attorney who, under subsection (1), files with the registrar a notice of resignation of attorney ceases to be an attorney for the extraprovincial non-share corporation on the later of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the beginning of the day that is 2 months and one day after the date on which the notice was filed with the registrar;
the beginning of the day that is the date specified in the attorney's resignation as the effective date of the resignation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, under section 170.1, the extraprovincial non-share corporation removes the attorney, the attorney ceases to be an attorney for the extraprovincial non-share corporation on the date the removal takes effect if that date is before the date referred to in subsection (2) (a) or (b), as applicable, of this section.
An extraprovincial non-share corporation may register under this Division only if the corporation complies with one of the following, as applicable:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the corporation reserves its own name under section 9 [name];
if the corporation's own name cannot be reserved, the corporation reserves, under section 9, an assumed name that meets the requirements of that section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an extraprovincial non-share corporation reserves an assumed name, the registrar may register the extraprovincial non-share corporation with its own name if it provides an undertaking to the registrar, in form and content satisfactory to the registrar, that it will carry on all of its activities in British Columbia under the assumed name, and, on such registration, that extraprovincial non-share corporation is deemed to have adopted the assumed name.
An extraprovincial non-share corporation that has adopted an assumed name under this section

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must acquire under its assumed name all property in British Columbia,
is entitled to all property acquired, and is subject to all liabilities incurred, under its assumed name as if the property and the liabilities had been acquired and incurred under its own name, and
may sue or be sued in its own name or its assumed name, or both.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An act of an extraprovincial non-share corporation that has adopted an assumed name under this Act, including a transfer of property to or by it, is not invalid merely because the act contravenes subsection (3) (a).
This section does not apply to a federal corporation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: To register, an extraprovincial non-share corporation must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file with the registrar a registration statement that sets out the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if the extraprovincial non-share corporation is a federal corporation, its name or, in any other case,

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the name reserved for it under section 9 [name] and the reservation number given for that name, unless section 171 applies to the extraprovincial non-share corporation, or
if section 171 applies to the extraprovincial non-share corporation, its name, the assumed name reserved for it under that section and the reservation number given for that assumed name;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: its home jurisdiction;
any incorporation or other identifying number given to it by its home jurisdiction and the date of its incorporation, amalgamation, continuation or other formation in that jurisdiction;
the delivery address and mailing address proposed for its head office;

for each person, if any, that the extraprovincial non-share corporation proposes to have as an attorney, the full name of the person and the delivery address and mailing address proposed for that person, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide to the registrar any other records and information the registrar may require, including proof satisfactory to the registrar of the status of the extraprovincial non-share corporation in its home jurisdiction.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After an extraprovincial non-share corporation complies with section 172 to the satisfaction of the registrar, the registrar

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must, if it is a federal corporation, and
may, in any other case,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: register the extraprovincial non-share corporation.
After an extraprovincial non-share corporation is registered, the registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: issue a certificate of registration in which is recorded

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the extraprovincial non-share corporation's name, assumed name, if any, and registration number, and
the date and time of the registration,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: furnish to the extraprovincial non-share corporation

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the certificate of registration, and
a certified copy of the registration statement the extraprovincial non-share corporation filed with the registrar under section 172 (a),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: furnish a copy of the registration statement the extraprovincial non-share corporation filed with the registrar under section 172 (a) to each attorney, if any, referred to in that registration statement, and
publish notice of the extraprovincial non-share corporation's registration.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Whether or not the requirements precedent and incidental to registration under this Division of an extraprovincial non-share corporation have been complied with, a notation in the register of societies that an extraprovincial non-share corporation has been registered under this Division is conclusive evidence for the purposes of this Act and for all other purposes that the extraprovincial non-share corporation has been duly registered under this Division with the name and any assumed name, and on the date and time, shown in the register of societies.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registrar may order change of name

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, for any reason, the name or assumed name of a registered extraprovincial non-share corporation is contrary to the requirements, if any, prescribed by regulation, or if the registrar, for good and valid reasons, disapproves of the name or assumed name of a registered extraprovincial non-share corporation, the registrar may, in writing and giving reasons, order the extraprovincial non-share corporation to change its name or assumed name, as the case may be, or to adopt an assumed name.
This section does not apply to a federal corporation.
In this section, charter includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the records of an extraprovincial non-share corporation that are similar to the constitution and bylaws of a society, and

the statute or other provision of law of the extraprovincial non-share corporation's home jurisdiction by or under which the extraprovincial non-share corporation is incorporated, amalgamated, continued or otherwise formed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this Act, to the other laws of British Columbia and to the laws of any other jurisdiction that are or may be applicable to it, a registered extraprovincial non-share corporation may, for the purpose of carrying on activities in British Columbia, exercise in British Columbia the powers contained in or permitted by its charter.
Registration of an extraprovincial non-share corporation does not entitle it to do either of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: carry on an activity or exercise a power that its charter restricts it from carrying on or exercising;
exercise any of its powers in a manner inconsistent with those restrictions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An act of an extraprovincial non-share corporation that carries on activities in British Columbia, including a transfer of property to or by it, is not invalid merely because

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the act is described in subsection (3) (a) or (b),
the extraprovincial non-share corporation was not, at the time of that act, registered under this Division, or
the act is contrary to section 183 [effect of cancellation of registration] or 188 (3) [effect of reinstatement].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Service of records on registered extraprovincial non-share corporation
bcl:section.bcl:text: Without limiting any other enactment, a record may be served on a registered extraprovincial non-share corporation

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by delivering the record, if the extraprovincial non-share corporation's head office is in British Columbia, to the delivery address of the head office or by mailing it by registered mail to the mailing address of that head office, or

by delivering the record to an attorney of the extraprovincial non-share corporation, which delivery may be made in accordance with section 30 [how record is delivered], by mailing it by registered mail to the mailing address of the attorney or by leaving the record at the delivery address of the attorney.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registered extraprovincial non-share corporation must file annual report

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a registered extraprovincial non-share corporation must, in each calendar year, file with the registrar an annual report.
Subsection (1) does not apply in the calendar year in which the extraprovincial non-share corporation is registered.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registered extraprovincial non-share corporation must notify registrar of changes

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registered extraprovincial non-share corporation must file with the registrar a notice of change in respect of any change that renders incorrect or incomplete any of the information shown with respect to the registered extraprovincial non-share corporation in the register of societies.
A notice of change required to be filed under subsection (1) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: set out

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the information the registrar requires, and

if the change reflected in the filing is a change of name and the extraprovincial non-share corporation does not have an assumed name, the new name reserved for it under section 9 [name] or, if that name cannot be reserved, the assumed name reserved for it under section 171 [assumed name], and the reservation number given for that name or assumed name, as the case may be, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be submitted to the registrar for filing promptly after the occurrence of the change.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) (a) (ii) does not apply to a federal corporation.
If a notice of change filed with the registrar under subsection (1) is in respect of a change of name, the registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: issue a certificate showing the change of name,
furnish the certificate to the extraprovincial non-share corporation, and
publish notice of the change of name.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Cancellation or change of assumed name

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A registered extraprovincial non-share corporation that has adopted an assumed name under this Act may, by filing with the registrar a notice of change of assumed name and providing to the registrar any other records or information the registrar may require,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the extraprovincial non-share corporation reserves its own name under section 9 [name], cancel its assumed name and carry on activities in British Columbia under its own name, or

if the extraprovincial non-share corporation reserves a new assumed name under section 171 [assumed name], change its assumed name and carry on activities in British Columbia under the new assumed name.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice of change of assumed name in respect of a registered extraprovincial non-share corporation must set out

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the information the registrar requires, and

the name or assumed name referred to in subsection (1) (a) or (b), as the case may be, reserved for the extraprovincial non-share corporation and the reservation number given for that name or assumed name.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After a registered extraprovincial non-share corporation cancels or changes its assumed name in accordance with this section, the registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: issue a certificate showing the cancellation or change of assumed name,
furnish the certificate to the extraprovincial non-share corporation, and
publish notice of the cancellation or change of assumed name.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a registered extraprovincial non-share corporation

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fails, for 2 consecutive calendar years, to file with the registrar an annual report required under this Act to be filed,
fails, for a period of at least 2 years, to file with the registrar a record, other than an annual report, required under this Act to be filed,
fails to pay a fee required under this Act to be paid to the registrar,
fails to comply with an order of the registrar,
fails to comply with section 170 [attorneys], or
breaches an undertaking under section 171 (2) [assumed name],

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the registrar may furnish to the extraprovincial non-share corporation a letter notifying it of its default and of the powers of the registrar under this section.

The registrar may furnish the letter referred to in subsection (1) to the head office of the registered extraprovincial non-share corporation, if the head office is in British Columbia, or to an attorney of that corporation.
Unless, within one month after the registrar furnishes the letter referred to in subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the default identified in the letter is remedied, or
the registrar receives a response that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: satisfies the registrar that reasonable steps are being taken to remedy the default, or
is otherwise satisfactory to the registrar,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the registrar may publish notice that, at any time after the expiration of one month after the date of the publication of notice, the registration of the registered extraprovincial non-share corporation may be cancelled unless cause to the contrary is shown to the registrar.

At any time after one month after the date of the publication of notice referred to in subsection (3) or, if an application for extension was filed with the registrar under subsection (5), at any time after the expiry of the extended period that results from that filing, the registrar may cancel the registration of the registered extraprovincial non-share corporation unless cause to the contrary is shown to the registrar.

A registered extraprovincial non-share corporation referred to in subsection (4) may file with the registrar an application for extension and, with that filing, the period after which the registrar may cancel the registration of the extraprovincial non-share corporation is extended

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a period of 6 months, or
if the registrar furnishes written notice to the extraprovincial non-share corporation indicating that a period longer than 6 months has been allowed, for the longer period referred to in the notice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless the registrar otherwise permits, a registered extraprovincial non-share corporation must not submit for filing more than one application for extension in relation to any one notice published under subsection (3).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Cancellation of registration of inactive or defunct extraprovincial non-share corporation
bcl:section.bcl:text: The registrar must cancel the registration of a registered extraprovincial non-share corporation if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person files with the registrar a notice, from the official in the extraprovincial non-share corporation's home jurisdiction whose role in that jurisdiction is similar to the role of the registrar in British Columbia, that that corporation has ceased to exist, or
the extraprovincial non-share corporation files with the registrar a notice that it has ceased to carry on activities in British Columbia.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Cancellation of registration by Lieutenant Governor in Council

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may cancel the registration of a registered extraprovincial non-share corporation.
Subsection (1) does not apply to a federal corporation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An extraprovincial non-share corporation whose registration is cancelled under this Division must cease carrying on activities in British Columbia.
After the registration of an extraprovincial non-share corporation is cancelled under this Division, the registrar must publish notice of the cancellation.
In this Division, applicant, in relation to an application under section 186 respecting an extraprovincial non-share corporation whose registration has been cancelled, means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the extraprovincial non-share corporation, or
an individual who, when the application is made, is a member of the board of directors or other governing body of the extraprovincial non-share corporation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the registration of an extraprovincial non-share corporation has been cancelled under this Part or under the former Act, an applicant may apply to the registrar under this section to reinstate the registration.

Before applying to the registrar to reinstate the registration of an extraprovincial non-share corporation, an applicant must reserve a name under section 9 [name] or an assumed name under section 171 [assumed name] for the extraprovincial non-share corporation whose registration is to be reinstated, unless it is a federal corporation.
To reinstate the registration of an extraprovincial non-share corporation under this section, an applicant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file with the registrar

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a reinstatement application, and
any other records the registrar may require, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide to the registrar any other records and information the registrar may require.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A reinstatement application must contain the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the name or assumed name, as the case may be, reserved for the extraprovincial non-share corporation and the reservation number given for that name or assumed name, unless that corporation is a federal corporation;
if the extraprovincial non-share corporation is a federal corporation, the name of that corporation;
the delivery address and mailing address proposed for the head office of the extraprovincial non-share corporation;

for each person, if any, that the extraprovincial non-share corporation proposes to have as an attorney, the full name of the person and the delivery address and mailing address proposed for that person;
if the reinstatement is for a limited period, a statement specifying the proposed limited period of the reinstatement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may establish the maximum period of reinstatement that may be specified in a statement referred to in subsection (4) (e).

After the reinstatement application is filed with the registrar under section 186, the registrar must, on any terms and conditions the registrar considers appropriate, reinstate the registration of the extraprovincial non-share corporation or reinstate the registration for the limited period set out in the application, as the case may be, with the same registration number the extraprovincial non-share corporation had before its registration was cancelled.

Despite subsection (1), the registrar may not reinstate under that subsection the registration of an extraprovincial non-share corporation, other than a federal corporation, unless the reservation of a name under section 9 [name] or an assumed name under section 171 [assumed name] for the extraprovincial non-share corporation remains in effect on the date of the reinstatement.
When the registration of an extraprovincial non-share corporation is reinstated under this Division,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: its name or assumed name is the name or assumed name, as the case may be, shown for the extraprovincial non-share corporation on the reinstatement application,
the delivery address and mailing address of the head office of the extraprovincial non-share corporation are the addresses shown for that office on the reinstatement application,
the delivery address and mailing address of the attorneys, if any, for the extraprovincial non-share corporation are the addresses shown for those attorneys on the reinstatement application, and
the registration is deemed not to have been cancelled, and, without limiting this, proceedings may be taken as if that registration had not been cancelled.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registration of an extraprovincial non-share corporation that is reinstated for a limited period is cancelled on the expiration of the limited period.
An extraprovincial non-share corporation whose registration is cancelled under subsection (2) must cease carrying on activities in British Columbia.
After the registration of an extraprovincial non-share corporation is cancelled under subsection (2), the registrar must publish notice of the cancellation.
After the registration of an extraprovincial non-share corporation is reinstated under this Division, the registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: issue a certificate of reinstatement in which is recorded

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the extraprovincial non-share corporation's name, assumed name, if any, and registration number,
the date and time of the reinstatement, and
in the case of a reinstatement for a limited period, the date on which the limited period of reinstatement expires,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: furnish to the extraprovincial non-share corporation

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the certificate of reinstatement, and
a certified copy of the reinstatement application filed with the registrar under section 186 [application for reinstatement of registration],

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: furnish to the applicant who filed the reinstatement application a copy of the certificate of reinstatement, and
publish notice of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the reinstatement, and
the date on which any limited period of reinstatement expires.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Whether or not the requirements precedent and incidental to reinstatement have been complied with, a notation in the register of societies that the registration of an extraprovincial non-share corporation has been reinstated is conclusive evidence for the purposes of this Act and for all other purposes that the registration of the extraprovincial non-share corporation has been duly reinstated with the name and any assumed name, and on the date and time, shown in the register of societies.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: allowable period, in relation to a person who has died, means the period, prescribed by regulation, preceding the person's death;
donations includes testamentary dispositions and gifts;
government funding means funding by way of a grant, a loan without interest or with interest substantially below the market rate or similar funding, provided by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the government of Canada, British Columbia or another province of Canada,
a municipality in British Columbia or in another province of Canada,
the governing body of a first nation in Canada, including the governing body of a band as defined in section 2 (1) of the Indian Act (Canada),
an organization that is owned or controlled by, or is an agent of, any of the governments or bodies referred to in paragraphs (a) to (c), or
a government, body or other organization that is included in this definition by regulation,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: but does not include funding excluded from this definition by regulation;
member-funded society means a society whose constitution contains a statement referred to in section 191 (1);
public donations means donations to a society, other than the following donations:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: donations excluded from this definition by regulation;
donations made by a person who is, at the time the donation is made,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a related donor,
the spouse of a related donor, or
the relative of a related donor or of the spouse of a related donor;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: donations made under a testamentary instrument of a person who was, within the allowable period,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a related donor,
the spouse of a related donor, or
the relative of a related donor or of the spouse of a related donor;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: related donor, in relation to a society, means any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a voting member of the society;
a director of the society;
a senior manager of the society;
an employee of the society.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Statement in constitution that member-funded society exists primarily for members

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 10 (2) [constitution] but subject to subsection (2) of this section, the constitution of a society may contain, in addition to the society's name and purposes, the following statement:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: This society is a member-funded society. It is funded primarily by its members to carry on activities for the benefit of its members. On its liquidation or dissolution, this society may distribute its money and other property to its members.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A society must not have a constitution that contains the statement referred to in subsection (1) if the society

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: except as provided in the regulations, has received during the period prescribed by regulation

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: public donations having a total value greater than the amount specified in, or calculated in accordance with, the regulations,
government funding having a total value greater than the amount specified in, or calculated in accordance with, the regulations, or
a combination of public donations and government funding having a total value greater than the amount specified in, or calculated in accordance with, the regulations,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is a registered charity as defined in section 248 (1) of the Income Tax Act (Canada) or is another qualified donee as defined in section 149.1 (1) of that Act,

is a designated recipient as defined in section 1 [definitions] of the Provincial Sales Tax Act or is otherwise entitled to receive taxes, fees or other revenue received by the government as agent of the society,
is a student society as defined in section 1 [definitions] of the College and Institute Act or section 1 [definitions] of the University Act,

is a hospital society as defined in section 42.1 [definitions for sections 42.1 to 42.4] of the Hospital Act or a society that owns, manages or operates a licensed community care facility, as defined in section 1 [definitions] of that Act, that is designated as a hospital society under section 42.4 (1) [further application of sections 42.2 and 42.3] of that Act, or
is in a class of societies that is prohibited under the regulations from having the statement in its constitution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A member-funded society

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must immediately alter its constitution to remove the statement referred to in section 191 (1) if the member-funded society is or becomes a society described in any of paragraphs (a) to (f) of section 191 (2), and
may, in any other case, alter its constitution to remove the statement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 15 [alterations to constitution] applies to an alteration referred to in subsection (1) of this section except that an alteration required by subsection (1) (a) of this section may be made without the authorization of a special resolution referred to in section 15 (2) (a).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Altering constitution to become member-funded society

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), a society may, by filing with the registrar a constitution alteration application, alter its constitution to include the statement referred to in section 191 (1) [statement in constitution that member-funded society exists primarily for members].
A society must not, under subsection (1), submit a constitution alteration application to the registrar for filing unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the alteration proposed by the application has been authorized by special resolution, and

the court, on the application of the society, has, by order, declared that the society is not prohibited under section 191 (2) from including in its constitution the statement referred to in section 191 (1).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A society that files with the registrar a constitution alteration application referred to in subsection (1) must, concurrently with that filing, file with the registrar a copy of the entered court order referred to in subsection (2) (b).
Section 15 (3) and (4) (a) [alterations to constitution] applies in respect of a constitution alteration under this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Other restrictions on becoming member-funded society

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A society must not, under section 87 (a) [application for amalgamation], submit to the registrar for filing an amalgamation application containing a constitution that includes the statement referred to in section 191 (1) [statement in constitution that member-funded society exists primarily for members] unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all of the amalgamating corporations are member-funded societies, or

the court, on the application of an amalgamating corporation, has, by order, declared that none of the amalgamating corporations that are not member-funded societies are prohibited under section 191 (2) from including the statement in its constitution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A society that files with the registrar an amalgamation application referred to in subsection (1) in respect of which a court order is required under subsection (1) (b) must, concurrently with that filing, file with the registrar a copy of the entered court order.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Access to financial statements of member-funded society
bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 28 [copies of financial statements] does not apply in relation to a member-funded society.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Reporting on remuneration for member-funded society
bcl:section.bcl:text: Section 36 [reporting on remuneration of directors, employees and contractors] does not apply in relation to a member-funded society.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 40 [number and residency of directors], a member-funded society need have only one director and none of the directors need be ordinarily resident in British Columbia.
Section 41 [employment of directors] does not apply in relation to a member-funded society.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Member-funded society may convert to company
bcl:section.bcl:text: A member-funded society may, under section 267.2 [conversion of member-funded societies] of the Business Corporations Act, be converted to a company as defined in section 1 (1) [definitions] of that Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Distribution of property before dissolution or on liquidation of member-funded society

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Section 124 (2) [distribution of property before dissolution or on liquidation] does not apply in relation to a member-funded society, and a distribution of money or other property under section 124 (1) (b) in respect of a member-funded society may be made

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to any person specified in the bylaws of the society, or

if the bylaws do not specify a recipient for such a distribution, to any person specified in an ordinary resolution of the society or, if passing an ordinary resolution is not feasible, specified in a directors' resolution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite section 126 [dissolution by request of society without assets or liabilities], in the case of a dissolution under that section of a member-funded society, the affidavit referred to in section 126 (3) (b) must set out that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the society has no liabilities or has made adequate provision for the payment of all of the society's liabilities in accordance with section 124 (1) (a), and
the remaining money or other property of the society, if any, has been distributed in accordance with section 124 (1) (b) and subsection (1) of this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of dissolution of member-funded society on joint tenancy
bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite section 154 (2) [effect of dissolution], on the dissolution of a member-funded society, any property held, immediately before the dissolution, by the society as a joint tenant devolves on the other joint tenants.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: designated words or initials, in relation to an occupational title society that is registered under this Division, means the word or combination of words, or the initials, designated by the registrar under section 88 (3) of the former Act as it read immediately before its repeal;
occupational title society means a society that has as one of its purposes the representation of the interests of an occupation or profession;
pre-existing application means an application for registration under section 88 of the former Act that is made on or before December 31, 2015 by a pre-existing society.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An occupational title society is registered under this Division if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the society was registered under Part 10 of the former Act immediately before its repeal or is registered under Part 10 of the former Act as it applies under section 202 (2) of this Act, and
the registration of the society has not been cancelled under this Division.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applications for registration by pre-existing occupational title societies

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the former Act is repealed on or before December 31, 2015, despite the repeal, a pre-existing society may apply on or before December 31, 2015 under section 88 of the former Act, as it read immediately before that repeal, for registration under Part 10 of the former Act.

Part 10 of the former Act as it read immediately before its repeal, despite that repeal, continues to apply for the purposes of a pre-existing application until a final determination respecting the registration of the pre-existing society under section 88 of the former Act is made in respect of that application.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Publication of names of registered occupational title societies
bcl:section.bcl:text: The registrar must publish in the manner described in section 211 [publication] a list of the names of the occupational title societies that are registered under this Division.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is not a member of an occupational title society that is registered under this Division must not use, in connection with an occupation or profession the person practises that is similar to the occupation or profession the society represents, the name of that society or the designated words or initials of that society in a way that identifies the person as a member of that society.

Registration under this Division of an occupational title society does not mean that the society, its qualifications for admission to membership or its members are in any way endorsed by the government.
Registration under this Division of an occupational title society does not affect any remedy that a person would have had if that society had not been registered under this Division.
An occupational title society that is registered under this Division may apply to the court for an injunction restraining a person from contravening section 204 (1) in relation to that society.

The court may grant an injunction sought under subsection (1) if satisfied that there is reason to believe that there has been or will be a contravention of section 204 (1) in relation to the occupational title society.
The court may grant an interim injunction until the outcome of a proceeding commenced under subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:text: An occupational title society that is registered under this Division must not, unless that society has first obtained the written consent of the registrar, submit a bylaw alteration application to the registrar for filing under section 17 [alterations to bylaws] in relation to a provision in the society's bylaws respecting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: qualifications for admission to membership or a class of membership,
courses of study and examinations for members or applicants for membership,
the conduct of members, ethics and standards of practice, or
suspension, expulsion or other penalties for misconduct, incapacity or incompetence of members.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The registrar may cancel the registration under this Division of an occupational title society if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registrar considers that continued registration is no longer in the public interest,
the society does not have at least 50 members in good standing,
the society alters its purposes to remove the purpose of representing the interests of an occupation or profession, or to change the occupation or profession whose interests are being represented,

the society submits a bylaw alteration application under section 17 [alterations to bylaws] without first obtaining the written consent of the registrar, if that consent is required under section 206, or
the society requests that the registration be cancelled.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Effect of restoration of dissolved occupational title society
bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite section 164 (5) [effect of restoration, extension or conversion], restoration under Division 11 [Restoration of Dissolved Society] of Part 10 [Liquidation, Dissolution and Restoration] of a dissolved society that was, on its dissolution, registered under Part 10 of the former Act or this Division does not restore the society's registration under this Division.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Act, a record is filed with the registrar when the registrar accepts the record and includes, in the register of societies, the information contained in the record.

A record that, under this Act, must or may be filed with the registrar, submitted to the registrar for filing or provided to the registrar must be filed, submitted or provided, as the case may be, in the manner the registrar requires.
Sections 407 (a) [means of filing] and 408 (1) (b) [filing of records] of the Business Corporations Act do not apply in relation to the filing of records with the registrar under this Act.

Despite sections 409 [future dated filing of records] and 410 [limitation on future dated filings] of the Business Corporations Act, a record submitted for filing to the registrar under this Act may not specify a date on which the filing of the record is to take effect that is later than the date on which the record is filed with the registrar.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Act, a record is furnished to a person by the registrar if the registrar provides the record to the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by mail to the mailing address for the person shown in the registrar's records,
if the person has provided an email address or fax number for that purpose, by email or fax to that email address or fax number,
by a method agreed to by the registrar and the person, or
by a method prescribed by regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of this Act, notice of a matter is published by the registrar if the registrar publishes notice of the matter

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a website maintained by or on behalf of the government, or
in another manner prescribed by regulation.

bcl:section.bcl:text: There must be paid to the registrar for the matters prescribed by regulation the fees prescribed by regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, minister means the minister prescribed by regulation for the purposes of this section.
The registrar must make a report to the minister if it appears to the registrar that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a society is conducting its activities with intent

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to defraud a person, or
to otherwise cause significant loss or damage to a person by acting unlawfully, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a society is carrying on activities that are detrimental to the public interest.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After receiving a report from the registrar under subsection (2) in relation to a society, the minister may appoint a person to conduct an investigation of the society and to make a written report to the minister of the investigator's findings.

An investigator appointed under subsection (3) may, in relation to the activities, internal affairs, accounts and records of or relating to the society being investigated, examine under oath a person who is or was a member, director or senior manager of the society or holds or held an equivalent position in a subsidiary of the society, or who is or was an employee, auditor, agent, trustee, banker, receiver, receiver manager or liquidator of the society or of a subsidiary of the society, and the investigator may administer the oath.
On examination under subsection (4), a person must answer any question relating to the society and must produce any records in that person's custody or control relating to the society.

After receiving a report from the registrar or after an investigation under this section, and subject to the conditions the minister considers advisable and to any order of the court, the minister may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order the society to conduct all or specified activities or internal affairs of the society in the manner specified in the order;
order the society to cease, for a specified period or permanently, all or specified activities of the society or the exercise of all or specified powers of the society;
recommend to the Lieutenant Governor in Council that the society be dissolved under section 215 [dissolution by Lieutenant Governor in Council].

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division, record keeper means, as applicable,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person who has, at the time of the dissolution of a society under this Division, custody or control of the records the society is required to keep under section 20 [records to be kept], or
any other person appointed by court order.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a society

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fails, for 2 consecutive calendar years, to file with the registrar an annual report required under this Act to be filed,
fails, for a period of at least 2 years, to file with the registrar a record, other than an annual report, required under this Act to be filed,
fails to file an annual report referred to in section 73 (4) [society must file annual report],
fails to pay a fee required under this Act to be paid to the registrar,
fails to comply with an order of the registrar,
fails to comply with an order of the minister under section 213 (6) (a) or (b),

fails to file a transition application referred to in section 240 [pre-existing society must file transition application] within the time set out in section 240 (1) or 244 (2) [transition of restored society], if applicable, or
